title: Friday, 10th August 2018
bodyHTML:
Alchemy30 morning, silence . . .
11:05 am
DM11:05am

Oh right, hello

Maverick Ahoy hoy Alchemy, very quiet morning indeed, other than House of Fraser and SPD
Blank canvas Hi all

Gosh, we've started then

DM11:05am

Markets Live, the thing with the words and the stocks

Manxish Happy Friday everyone

DM11:08am

A long time ago, when I worked at Citi, for some reason it was my job to get on the phone to the radio network which broadcast to all the retail stock brokers in their network at 1.30pm in London, to give them a two minute update on what was happening in "international markets".

DM11:08am

Once you've done that 50 times, the way to liven it up is to leave it as late as possible to get back from lunch and start tapping on the bloomberg as you dial

11:09 am

Hi, er yes, things were happening today in Europe

Soundbuy 'leave it as late as possible to get back from lunch'............great training for the FT :)
DM11:10am

Which is a longwinded way of saying we have a seat of the pants session today, as I've been writing something on short sellers in America, which should appear in the actual newspaper tomorrow

Alchemy30 any sneak preview ?
irishobserver So what’s happening in europe today?
DM11:11am

So, its a Friday in August

Stateless Happy Friday
irishobserver Yes happy friday

We'll take it gentle, and requests welcome on the right

Blue horseshoe... Spire looks interesting following director buys yday.Mediclinic must be tempted
undefined
sprout you could blow your own trumpet and note the damage to certain eurozone banks from your Turkey/ECB scoop today.

Turkey getting a lot of attention inside the building

Mouselet Good morning assorted people
11:15 am

Turkish Lira at 5.9295 to the dollar, which isn't as bad as the 6.2860 high of earlier

Much of this seems to be the FT excellent story of worry's within the ECB

Pharma #Turkey, saw a list of bank exposures in the paper this morning. The usual suspects (BBVA, BNP Paribas, Unicredit), but also HSBC. Any grey on potential damage if the loans go bad?

11:17 am

See also Colby Smith's excellent post on hard currency obligations from Monday Morning

Shrink Much neater than BE I'd say.
DM11:19am

From my colleagues I learn that n Turkey, the finance minister is due to present his “new economic model” at 1430 local (1230 London), pushed back from this morning.

11:20 am
DM11:20am

We also have a US effect, with Sanctions also troubling our friends in the East

Pharma @DM, I assume your short seller piece is a bit more informative than the "big oil shorting Tesla" headline I saw today.
DM11:21am

Here was a bit of Deutsche grey this morning, the dependable Jim Reid

DM11:22am

As of three hours ago

11:21 am
DM11:22am

Meanwhile the Turkish Lira dropped -5.15% to a fresh record low (YTD -46.2%) and the 13th worst day since 2000. Ankara’s jailing of the America pastor and the associated diplomatic row continues to hurt the country’s assets. Not even the Turkish Treasury and Finance Minister Berat Albayrak’s office saying that the government would curb sovereign borrowing by reducing the GDP growth target to under 4% from 5.5% had an impact beyond a brief and small intra-day tick up in the Lira. President Erdogan speaks today at 2pm local time so it’ll be interesting to see if anything important comes from that. Meanwhile the Russian Ruble fell -1.72% (YTD -15.7%) to the lowest since April 2016 as the prior night’s US sanctions continued to dampen sentiment. Countries that are in a diplomatic battle with the US at the moment (e.g. China, Turkey and Russia) seems to be suffering in the markets.

Swedish Chef Erdogan “if they have dollars, we have God” I’ll stick with the greenback.
DM11:23am

(@Pharma It's more on how Shorting is mainstream these days)

Swedish Chef Although to be fair, both religion and the international banking system are faith based constructs.
DM11:23am

And UBS has just landed

11:23 am
DM11:24am

At a cross roads again? wonders Gyorgy Kovacs

DM11:24am

In the past the increase in TRY volatility and/or a rise in dollarization were the most common indicators signalling an upcoming Central Bank of Turkey monetary tightening; and not the TRY crossing certain thresholds against the USD or EUR. The lira volatility (3m) has once again risen back to the territory which prompted the CBT to hike rates by 300bps on 23 May, though deposit dollarization rates continued to decline. We think the cause here is that the recent round of very rapid TRY depreciation – the lira has lost 22% since 26 July – has much to do with rapid public escalation of tensions between the US and Turkey. The escalation has resulted in, according to the press, the US placing sanctions on two Turkish ministers, the US Trade Representative's office considering the withdrawal of duty-free access for USD 1.7bn worth of Turkish exports and previously (20 July) a US Senate committee supporting the "Turkey International Financial Institutions Act" bill.

DM11:24am

We are into crisis hike territory

11:24 am
DM11:25am

350-400bps rate hike would get real rates consistent with past TRY stability
We believe that the worsening inflation outlook – on account of the announced 9% increase in both household gas and electricity tariffs and due to the impact of TRY depreciation on inflation – is consistent with inflation reaching 16% y/y in the short-term and potentially still being between 14-15% y/y by end-2018. This scenario would hold even if the TRY were to recuperate some of its losses in the coming months. Looking at different measures of real rates (using current CPI, or different forward looking measures) we think a rate hike of 350-400bps to 21.25%-21.75% from 17.75% looks consistent with real rate levels that in the past helped to stabilize the currency. If we look at the real deposit rates in the banking system, a 350-400bps hike would also lift real deposit rates into safer territory. Both the nominal and real lending rates are already high on consumer and corporate loans, thus a rate hike should bring a further slowdown in credit growth – which has already plummeted to below 6%. The FX Swap curve is pricing the tightening at the following rate: 1m +280, 2m +280, 3m +300, 6m +340, 9m +355 and 1y +355bps.

Stateless I really don't want to see Turkey going the way of the dictatorship
Pharma @Swedish, and US Dollars say "In God We Trust".
DM11:25am

But it may also require a reversal of fiscal stimulus, which would not be popular?

Swedish Chef Pharmacy Allah Akbar it is then.
DM11:27am

Does the IMF come knocking at some point, or is this another opportunity for China, as in Pakistan with all the belt and road money (which comes with strings, also read Colby here )

Stateless @Pharma, it also says - "this note is legal tender, both public and private"

Stocks stocks stocks

DM11:29am

Mike Ashley, Britain's answer to Jeff Bezos

He is very good at buying things cheaply which other people don't want

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 405.00, down 1.7 (-0.42%), High: 410.30, Low: 403.57, Volume: 237.56k
A. M. @DM: thought you were referring to the employment practices in their warehouses..

Market shrugs as he swoops on House of Fraser for £90m

DM11:31am

Stifel can handle the details

DM11:31am

With a last-minute move, Mike Ashley takes over the totality of House of Fraser for £90m. The offer comes after the news of House of Fraser's administration was spread in the first hours of the day. Mike Ashley's plan for the retailer is unknown, but the CVA of HoF had 31 store closures and 6,000 job cuts planned. Within our coverage, Debenhams (Hold, 12p) and Quiz Clothing shares (Buy, 167p) are the most likely to be affected by the transaction.

Shinshin HoF - has he bought the biz or bought the assets out of admin ? Much different set of liabilities between the two.
11:31 am
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 11.73, up 0.21 (+1.82%), High: 11.92, Low: 11.67, Volume: 1.59m
DM11:32am

The read across fading slightly there

DM11:32am

Debenhams' shares (Sports Direct owns a 29.7% stake) were up 3% this morning as House of Fraser's administration appeared final: while short-term pain was expected on the back of HoF's inventory clearance, it would have increased demand for Debenhams and John Lewis over Christmas trading, the most important trading period of the year. Both companies are due to report their results on 13 September and 25 October.

Pharma Sports Direct, Debenhams and now House of Fraser. Is Mike Ashley trying for the Monopoly set of crap retailers? What is needed to make it up to four?

So, I really need to flesh this out further, but Ashley is basically the only person investing in the high street

Swedish Chef L&G ? I’m all ears.
DM11:46am

We maintain our 12-month target price at GBP2.90, reflecting 2.1x 2018 consensus P/B with a 19% ROE. This is in largely line with its 5-year mean but above peers at 1.6x, to reflect its higher ROE (peers average: 13%). 1H 2018 EPS of GBp13 was broadly in line with consensus, but we revise up our EPS forecast for 2018 and 2019 as we expect stronger profit in 2H 2018 contributed by better mortality releases. 1H 2018 annuity sales in LGR came in at GBP1.1 billion (-49%yoy) as the business is lumpy in nature. However, LGEN stated that 2H 2018 sales will be boosted by a large deal which it is closing now. We think it is important to monitor the margin of the new annuity sale. Operating profit from continuing operation rose 7% with LGR division rose by 9%. LGIM's profit came in slightly weak due to lower asset management revenues. While the result was decent, we think that these have been priced in mostly.

A. M. @Mouselet: scaled-up made-to-measure?

Day late hold notes, don't ever say I don't treat you

Pharma @Mouselet, and which of those three measurements should a shopper choose, given they are not particularly well correlated.
Mouselet all three!
Mouselet you put all three in the website and it says 'this lime-green mankini is pretty good but 2cm too tall; this purple leopard-print onesie is a bit tight on the hips; this scarlet tutu is just right'
Mouselet parametric search is not intrinsically a thing for electronic components
Pharma @Mouselet, that sounds like automated made to measure, which is going to work better with an order, make, deliver model.
DM11:48am

Liberum have a buy note out on Stroer, which catches the eye both as it once was a shortie target, and also Google is getting into outdoor ads?

Mouselet All I'm suggesting is measuring the clothes on the rack and listing the measurements on the web site
11:48 am
DM11:48am

An article in the German press suggests Google would aim to connect its Doubleclick to existing digital out-of-home screens. Initially this should improve the utilisation rate of screens and allow late advertising money to enter the market due to the quicker turnaround of an advertising campaign. However, with the OOH contracts generally being 10-30 years old we believe it is unlikely that Google will be a game changer for the outdoor names in the near term.

Mouselet no automation required (indeed, you would need to hire several minions with tailor's tapes to measure the clothes)
DM11:49am

Stoer is outdoor ads, for the uninitiated

Mouselet order-make-deliver-return is a great way to make your venture capitalists look at you without joy in their dark cold eyes
DM11:51am

And we take one more step towards a Black Mirror/Minority Report world. Can't wait till Google starts flashing up things you've already bought on billboards as you walk past

alewis2005 @DM are you going to hold a wake for Ms Scaggs?
11:51 am
DM11:52am

Anyway, this is good for Stroer, apparently

DM11:52am

In a first instance, Google aiming to use Doubleclick to monetise existing screens is positive for the OOH players as it will allow them to get the usage of the digital screens up, which implicitly should also raise prices. Applying Doubleclick to the DOOH, same as inventory trading automation, should allow to get advertising campaigns up in a much speedier way than traditionally and therefore allow new (late) advertising money to flow into the OOH sector.

In terms of the long-term implications we do not see Google as a threat with the OOH market having mostly long term 10-30 year concessions, which means that Google would have to wait a long time to even potentially mark its presence in the OOH market. If Google wants to see a quicker increase in share it would have to acquire either Ströer or JCDecaux's German assets.

Pharma When faced with the prospect of using a tape measure, and risk discovering your waist has expanded, or just scattergun ordering and then returning, I think the latter will win out.
undefined
Sails Surely is just needs Alphabet, Apple or someone to adapt/improve the new camera tech to scan a body and automatically find the measurements (you go the changing room, take your clothes off and step into an enclosing cubicle which scans you 360 deg) which are then fed to the automatic sewing machine? '30 minutes for a new made-to-measure suit!'

Lemmy Mouselet: it's not that far off, I've seen factories in South Korea cutting fabric via laser, stitching by robot all using algorithms to cut the cloth with the least waste etc
11:57 am
DM11:57am

UBS have turned buyers on the basis of undervalued capital optionality, obvs

Mouselet automatic cutting out of pieces is straightforward. stitching the pieces together is a metric bugger on stilts.
DM11:57am

RBS' 2Q18 pre-provision profit generation was in line with market expectations but capital generation was again much stronger than forecast: CET1 at 16.1% is £4bn or 13% of market cap above target despite consigning the DOJ RMBS investigation, £2bn in pension contributions and a chunk of restructuring spend to history. The first dividend in a decade didn't dent the balance sheet either: significant special dividends or buybacks – perhaps direct from government – are needed to stop this undervalued surplus capital from growing further. We think earnings and excess capital are undervalued at a buyback-adjusted medium term P/E of 6-7x; upgrade to Buy.

Sails interesting Lemmy
Mouselet one proposed solution was 'starch the fabric until it is like hardboard, stitch as if rigid, wash afterwards', but that's not very 30-minute-process
DM11:58am

Bank buybacks are probably a post-not-hard-brexit scenario kind of affair, but there you go

11:59 am

undefined
